metadata.title: Create a Supervised Model in 30 Hours Or Less | by Miri Yehezkel | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Create a Supervised Model in 30 Hours Or Less
metadata.description: This post was created during the #30_hours program of Baot, Israel’s largest community of senior female engineers and computer scientists. In the 30 hours program, participants invest 30 hours (over…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: visualization provided for this dataset on Kaggle
feature selection and how to identify relevant features

all_paragraphs: This post was created during the #30_hours program of Baot, Israel’s largest community of senior female engineers and computer scientists. In the 30 hours program, participants invest 30 hours (over 4 months) to further their knowledge in a new field, by building a personal or a group project with a professional mentor.
In a real-world scenario, you might have to gather the data to start with. We’ll skip this step and use the Kaggle House Prices dataset in this post.
In this dataset, we have both the houses data — such as the state of the house, its location and data on when it was sold — and the price the house was sold for.
We can use supervised learning to train a model to map the given inputs (called features, such as house condition and location) to the given output (called label, such as the sale price).
First, let’s read the csv file using pandas. The label is denoted by y:
Next, we’ll see which features can help us predict the price of a house.
Before we can select the features, we need to understand what our data looks like. Let’s start with the data columns:
We have 80 columns that can help us predict the SalePrice. Let’s have a closer look at each column. We’ll use 2 methods to investigate our data:

In the example below, we can see there are two unique values for “Street”, and almost all of them are “Pave”. We can also see most “Alley” values are missing. Since these data columns aren’t varied, we can’t learn how prices differ across streets or alleys.

To simplify the process of investigating the data, you can use the visualization provided for this dataset on Kaggle to gain more insight on each data column. You can also look at my code example here.

We want to choose only the features that help us predict the price of a house in order to reduce computational cost and improve the performance of the model — this process is called Feature Selection.
We will simplify this process for this example, but you can read more on feature selection and how to identify relevant features.
Here’s a simplified feature selection example. Features are denoted by X:

The model’s job is to find patterns in the data in order to predict the label — the patterns are derived from the data the model trains on. In order to get an unbiased evaluation of the model’s accuracy, we need to validate it against data it hasn’t trained on.
We do that by splitting the data into (at least) 3 section:

Since we’re using a Kaggle competition dataset, we already have a test set provided for us under a different file (test.csv). We will only need to split the train set into train and validation.We do that using train_test_split, which splits the data into two sections.Later on we’ll see how the validation set helps us tune our model.
the random_state value is set to some constant to avoid randomness when training models.

We’re using scikit-learn, a machine learning library in Python, to create the model. Scikit-learn (or sklearn) expects data to be numerical and meaningful. Real world data might have missing values, or it may contain values that are not numerical (categorical values, images, etc) and is therefore incompatible with scikit-learn.
Before we can train the model, we need to prepare the data so that we can feed it to scikit-learn. This step is called — you guessed it — preprocessing!

We want to encode the categorical data to numerical data. We can do that using different encoders. For example, we can use the ordering of the categories with label encoding. If the categories have no ordering, we can use one-hot encoding, which creates a new feature for each category and fills it with boolean values. Read more on cleaning and preprocessing data.
Create an encoder for categorical values — it this example we’ll use OneHotEncoder, but the choice can and should vary depending on your data:
You can go a step further and preprocess numerical data to create an even more accurate model!
It’s almost time to fit the model!
We saw how we can impute missing values and encode categorical values. Let’s define those steps in a pipeline to make our code cleaner and easier to debug.
We define a pipeline for each column type in our data, in our case we need to handle numerical and categorical data:
Great, we now have a pipeline for each column type. Let’s bundle these preprocessing steps for the data columns:

Note that in the example, we’re bundeling the preprocessing steps by numerical/categorical data — in reality, you’d want to use steps that best match your data columns. When investigating the data, you should see which preprocessing steps are best for different columns rather than using a “one size fits all” approach.
Now that we have defined our preprocessing for the training set, we can use it to train our model!
You might be asking yourself — shouldn’t we preprocess all of the data, not just the training set?

The answer is definitely no! If we preprocess based on all of the data we’ll gain insight into the data we’re validating against, resulting in a false positive evaluation! Including information from outside the train set is called data leakage.
Now let’s fit the model using the pipeline!

Supervised models can either be classification models, which output a discrete result such as predicting whether an email is spam or not, and regression models, which output a continous result such as predicting house prices. Read more on common ML models.
We’ll use a Random Forest regression model — an ensemble of decision trees.
Define a pipeline for preprocessing and fitting a Random Forest Regressor model:

This is where we finally use the validation set.n_estimators is a numeric hyperparameter of the RandomForestRegressor model. We can use different n_estimators values to create and evaluate our model against the validation set, ultimately choosing the value the gives us the closest prediction to the actual label on the validation data — doing that causes our model to be tuned by the validation set, which is why we need to have a test set, a dataset the model hasn’t seen or has been tuned by. n_estimators is also used to control underfitting and overfitting in the example model.
We can now use that pipeline to fit our model using all the previously defined steps:
Aaaaaand… we finally have a fitted model!

Can the model successfully predict house prices on data it hasn’t seen? Let’s test the model using a Loss Function — a function that helps us calculate the “cost” of the difference between the original label and the predicted label, which helps us estimate how accurate the model is.

A common loss functions we can use is MAE (mean absolute error), which computes the absolute difference between the original label and the predicted label — lower MAE score means better predictions on the validation data.
You can play with different hyperparameter values, features, models and preprocessing steps to see how the model’s score changes.
Now that you have a model you’re satisfied with, you can save the predictions to a .csv file, upload it to Kaggle and move on to the next challenge!
You can find a link to the full code at the end of this post.
If this blogpost helped you, feel free to share it with your friends!

Autodidact software developer. Enjoys expanding and sharing knowledge, and passionate about encouraging growth in myself and others.
